title: What is Project Management?
description: Discover the core definition of project management and how it differs from operations.
objectives: Distinguish between projects (temporary, unique) and operations (ongoing, repetitive)
Understand the triple constraint (scope, time, cost) and how balancing these factors impacts quality
Identify project success factors: meeting objectives, stakeholder satisfaction, delivering value
Recognize when work should be managed as a project vs. operational work

screens.headline: Alex's First Day: Three Past 'Projects' That Failed

items.title: Menu Launch
items.details: 6 months late, 50% over budget, customers hated it

items.title: New POS System
items.details: Implemented but no one trained, still using paper

dialogue.text: We've tried new initiatives before. They all failed or cost too much. You're here to fix that. But first—what exactly IS project management? And why can't we just handle these like our normal restaurant work?

screens.learningHook: Not all work is the same. Projects are temporary and unique. Operations are ongoing and repetitive. The difference determines success or failure.

screens.title: Classify the Work at Savory & Co.
screens.instructions: Carlos shows you three types of work happening this month. For each one, decide if it's a PROJECT or OPERATIONS.

scenarios.title: Daily Food Service
description: Quality control through tasting, customer feedback

questions.question: Is this a PROJECT or OPERATIONS?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Daily food service is ONGOING (no end date) and REPETITIVE (same menu, same processes). This is operations, not a project.
feedback.incorrect: Not quite. Daily food service has no end date (ongoing) and repeats the same menu daily (not unique). Projects are TEMPORARY and UNIQUE.

scenarios.title: Menu Innovation Lab (Seasonal Menu Launch)
description: Develop 12 new dishes for fall/winter season
After launch, new menu becomes part of daily operations

questions.question: Is this a PROJECT or OPERATIONS?

feedback.correct: Exactly! Menu Innovation Lab is TEMPORARY (ends October 1) and UNIQUE (developing 12 new dishes never created before).
feedback.incorrect: This is actually a PROJECT. It's TEMPORARY (ends October 1) and UNIQUE (new dishes never created before). After launch, serving these dishes becomes operations.

questions.question: Match the three constraints to the project details:

items.label: Scope
items.match: 12 new dishes, tested and ready for launch

feedback.correct: Perfect! You identified the triple constraint: Scope (12 new dishes), Time (October 1 deadline), Cost ($25K budget).
feedback.incorrect: Review the three constraints: Scope = what will be delivered, Time = when it's due, Cost = budget available.

questions.question: What happens if the project team focuses ONLY on time (meeting October 1 deadline)?

options.text: Scope or cost likely increases (rush fees, untested dishes)

feedback.correct: Exactly! Focusing ONLY on the deadline creates pressure. The team might cut corners on testing, pay rush fees, or reduce dish count. The triple constraint is interconnected.
feedback.incorrect: The triple constraint is interconnected. Forcing the deadline might cause: cutting corners (quality suffers), rush fees (cost increases), or reducing dishes (scope decreases).

scenarios.title: Restaurant Expansion (New Location Opening)
description: Open second Savory & Co. location across town
Site selection, construction, permits, hiring, training
After opening, new location operates independently

questions.question: Is this a PROJECT or OPERATIONS?

feedback.correct: Right! Restaurant expansion is TEMPORARY (ends at grand opening) and UNIQUE (each location has unique site, permits, local market).
feedback.incorrect: This is a PROJECT. It's TEMPORARY (ends at grand opening) and UNIQUE (specific site, permits, market). After opening, running the restaurant becomes operations.

questions.question: Carlos says: "Just focus on getting it open fast. We'll worry about budget later." What's the risk?

options.text: No risk—time is most important for competitive advantage
Cost overruns likely (rushing = overtime, expedited permits, premium contractors)

feedback.correct: Exactly! Focusing ONLY on time ignores cost and scope. Rush construction leads to premium rates, expedited fees, overtime pay, and corners cut.
feedback.incorrect: Focusing ONLY on time (speed) ignores cost and scope. The triple constraint means you can't ignore one dimension without consequences.

content.definition: A project is a TEMPORARY endeavor undertaken to create a UNIQUE product, service, or result.

keyPoints.explanation: Has a defined beginning and end (not ongoing forever)
Creates something that hasn't been done before (not repetitive)

projects: Menu Innovation Lab (ends October 1, unique dishes)
Restaurant Expansion (ends at grand opening, unique location)
operations: Daily food service (ongoing indefinitely, same menu/processes repeated daily)

content.insight: Projects CREATE or CHANGE things. Operations MAINTAIN things.

content.definition: Operations are ONGOING processes that produce REPETITIVE outputs.
characteristics: No end date (continues as long as the business exists)
examples: Daily food service (same menu, same customers, indefinitely)
content.insight: After a project ENDS, its deliverables often become OPERATIONS.

content.definition: Every project must balance three competing constraints:
balancingAct: Increase Scope → Time or Cost must increase (or quality decreases)
Decrease Time → Cost increases or Scope decreases or Quality suffers
Decrease Cost → Time increases or Scope decreases or Quality suffers
content.insight: Quality is at the center—impacted by how you balance scope, time, and cost.
content.pmbokRef: Traditional Iron Triangle, evolved in PMBOK 7th to Performance Domains

content.definition: Project management is the application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet project requirements.

components.name: Knowledge
components.detail: Understanding frameworks (PMBOK, Agile), best practices, lessons learned

components.name: Tools
components.detail: Schedules (Gantt charts), budgets, risk registers, stakeholder maps

pmJob: Determine WHEN it will be done (time)
Estimate HOW MUCH it will cost (cost)
content.insight: Project management is NOT just 'getting things done.' It's systematically applying proven methods to deliver value within constraints.

content.traditionalView: On time, on budget, meets scope (triple constraint)

factors.name: Meets Objectives
factors.detail: Did the project achieve its intended purpose?

factors.name: Stakeholder Satisfaction
factors.detail: Are customers, sponsors, and team happy with the result?

factors.name: Delivers Value
factors.detail: Did the project create business value or benefit?

example.traditional: Opened on time (6 months), within budget ($850K), with all scope
example.valueDriven: Is the new location profitable? Do customers love it? Did it achieve market expansion?

dialogue.text: We've had projects finish 'on time and on budget' that failed because customers hated the result. Success is about VALUE, not just checking boxes.

content.pmbokRef: PMBOK 7th Ed emphasizes value delivery and stakeholder outcomes

correct.text: Right. We've been running daily service for 10 years. That's operations. But when we want to create something NEW—that's a project.

incorrect.text: If daily service were a project, it would have an end date. But we serve customers every day, indefinitely. That's operations.

correct.text: Once we launch the new menu on October 1, the project ends. Then serving those dishes daily becomes part of operations.
I've said 'just get it done fast' on past projects. Now I understand why we went 50% over budget every time. You can't ignore cost constraints.

screens.title: New Challenge: Technology Upgrade
screens.context: Carlos presents a new initiative: upgrading Savory & Co.'s point-of-sale (POS) system across all 3 locations.

scenario.title: POS System Upgrade
details: Research and select new POS vendor
Migrate customer data from old system
Train all staff (15 people per location = 45 total)

questions.question: Is this a PROJECT or OPERATIONS?

feedback.correct: Correct! TEMPORARY (ends at go-live, 90 days), UNIQUE (first time upgrading POS). After go-live, using the POS daily becomes operations.
feedback.incorrect: This is a PROJECT. It's TEMPORARY (ends at go-live) and UNIQUE (first POS upgrade for Savory & Co.).

questions.question: Identify the triple constraint for this project:

items.label: Scope
items.match: New POS at 3 locations, data migrated, staff trained

questions.question: Carlos says: "We can't afford delays. Do whatever it takes to hit the deadline." Which outcomes are LIKELY?
questions.instruction: Swipe RIGHT for Likely, LEFT for Not Likely

cards.statement: Quality will be compromised to meet the deadline
cards.explanation: Rushing typically sacrifices testing and finishing work

cards.statement: Cost will increase due to overtime or rush fees
cards.explanation: "Whatever it takes" often means paying premium rates

cards.statement: Scope will be cut to fit the timeline
cards.explanation: When time is fixed, scope reduction is common
"Do whatever it takes" creates unsustainable pressure
Rushing typically increases costs, not reduces them

feedback.high: You understand the triple constraint. Forcing time creates pressure on cost, scope, AND quality.
feedback.low: You missed some key risks. The triple constraint means you CAN'T force one dimension without impacting the others.

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've learned the fundamental difference between projects and operations, and why the triple constraint forces trade-offs.
takeaways: Projects are TEMPORARY and UNIQUE (have an end date, create something new)
Operations are ONGOING and REPETITIVE (no end date, maintain the business)
Triple Constraint: Every project must balance Scope (what), Time (when), Cost (how much)
Interconnected: You can't optimize one constraint without impacting the others
Project Success: Not just on time/budget/scope—must deliver VALUE and satisfy STAKEHOLDERS
Project Management: Applying knowledge, skills, tools, techniques to meet requirements

characterClosing.text: I've been treating everything the same—daily service and new initiatives. Now I see: operations maintain the business, projects CHANGE it. We need both.
